description: Learn the fundamentals of JavaScript: Variables, Data Types, Operators, and Syntax.

slides.title: What is JavaScript?
slides.content:
# JavaScript ‚ö°

JavaScript is the programming language of the Web.

- **HTML** is for Content.
- **CSS** is for Layout.
- **JavaScript** is for Behavior.

It can update and change both HTML and CSS, and calculate, manipulate and validate data.

slides.title: Adding JavaScript
slides.content:
# The <script> Tag üìú

You can insert JavaScript code into HTML using the `<script>` tag.

```html
<script>
  document.getElementById("demo").innerHTML = "My First JavaScript";
</script>
```

Or link to an external file:
```html
<script src="myScript.js"></script>
```

slides.title: Variables
slides.content:
# Variables üì¶

Variables are containers for storing data values.

There are 3 ways to declare a variable:
- `var` (Old, function-scoped)
- `let` (Modern, block-scoped, reassignable)
- `const` (Modern, block-scoped, constant)

```javascript
let x = 5;
const pi = 3.14;
var name = "John";
```

slides.title: Data Types
slides.content:
# Data Types üíæ

JavaScript has dynamic types. The same variable can hold different data types.

- **String**: `"Hello World"`
- **Number**: `3.14` or `42`
- **Boolean**: `true` or `false`
- **Undefined**: A variable without a value.
- **Null**: Represents "nothing".
- **Object**: `{firstName:"John", lastName:"Doe"}`

slides.title: Operators
slides.content:
# Arithmetic Operators ‚ûï

Perform arithmetic on numbers.

- `+` Addition
- `-` Subtraction
- `*` Multiplication
- `/` Division
- `%` Modulus (Remainder)
- `++` Increment
- `--` Decrement

```javascript
let x = 10;
let y = x % 3; // Result is 1
```

slides.title: Assignment Operators
slides.content:
# Assignment Operators üü∞

Assign values to variables.

- `=` Simple assignment
- `+=` Add and assign (`x += y` is `x = x + y`)
- `-=` Subtract and assign
- `*=` Multiply and assign

```javascript
let x = 10;
x += 5; // x is now 15
```

slides.title: Strings
Comments
slides.content:
# JS Comments üí¨

Comments are ignored by the browser.

```javascript
// This is a single line comment

/*
This is a 
multi-line comment
*/
```

slides.title: Comparison Operators
slides.content:
# Comparison ‚öñÔ∏è

Used in logic statements.

- `==` Equal to (value only)
- `===` Equal value and equal type (Strict)
- `!=` Not equal
- `!==` Not equal value or not equal type
- `>` Greater than
- `<` Less than

```javascript
5 == "5" // true
5 === "5" // false
```

slides.title: Logical Operators
slides.content:
# Logical Operators üß†

Use to determine the logic between variables or values.

- `&&` AND
- `||` OR
- `!` NOT

```javascript
let x = 6;
let y = 3;

(x < 10 && y > 1) // true
(x == 5 || y == 5) // false
!(x == y) // true
```

slides.title: Output
slides.content:
# Displaying Output üñ•Ô∏è

Four ways to output data in JavaScript:

1.  `innerHTML`: Write into an HTML element.
2.  `document.write()`: Write into HTML output (testing mostly).
3.  `window.alert()`: Write into an alert box.
4.  `console.log()`: Write to browser console (debugging).

```javascript
console.log("Debug message here");
```

slides.title: Naming Conventions
slides.content:
# Camel Case üê´

JavaScript variables are case-sensitive.

The convention is **Type Lower Camel Case**:

Start with a lowercase letter, and capitalize each subsequent word.

- `firstName`
- `masterCard`
- `interCity`

slides.title: Code Example
Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: JS Basics üéì

Your first steps into logic.

- **Variables:** `let`, `const`, `var`.
- **Types:** String, Number, Boolean, Object.
- **Operators:** Logic (`&&`, `||`) and Math (`+`, `-`).
- **Comparison:** `===` is strictly better than `==`.
- **Output:** `console.log()` is your friend.
